results.title: Late for dinner: was Dawn right?
results.creator_credit: Gary Bergland and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Dawn, an Afro-American aged around eight, and her two friends have gone to play in the park. Dawn’s mother has told her it is very important she is home on time for dinner and stresses for her not to be late. However on her way home, Dawn collides with a woman running to catch a bus and in the confusion the woman drops a five-dollar bill. The woman boards her bus before Dawn can return the money. Dawn attempts to catch up with the bus but fails and consequently she arrives home late for dinner with money that doesn’t belong to her. Before she can explain, her mother begins to scold her - “Why are you late?” Helps children see that conflicting feelings are both common and normal. Set in the tenament area of Chicago. Part of the “How does it make you feel?” series. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Latcho drom : safe journey = Latcho drom : bonne route
results.creator_credit: Tony Gatlif, Michele Ray-Gavras and K G Productions
results.brief_description: A masterpiece by Tony Gatlif is a “docu-musical” which explores the rich cultural, social heritage of the world’s Gypsies. The program is a political statement about the persecution suffered by Gypsies but is presented as a celebration of their music, dance and song from the around the globe. Singers, dancers and musicians from India, Egypt, Turkey, Romania, Hungary, Slovakia, France and Spain are featured. This is an energetic, powerful, joyous experience.

results.title: Last stand
results.creator_credit: Frank Rijavec, Claire Calzoni and Coalition for Denmark's Environment (W.A.)
results.brief_description: Western Australia had 5% forest cover at settlement. In 150 years that has been reduced to just 1%. “Last Stand” is a critical examination of south Western Australia’s natural forest reserves and present forest practices which threatens the remaining ancient Karri Forests. It sounds a timely warning that whole areas af Australia’s wilderness will be lost to future generations if short term commercial gain is the sole criteria for their management.

results.title: Last paradise. Parts 1-3
results.creator_credit: Gian Manara and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: An educational documentary in three parts, ‘Last Paradise’ examines the contrasts between contemporary and traditional lifestyles in Papua New Guinea through the lives of flight crew members working for the country’s national airline, Air Niugini. While they enjoy the privileged lifestyles of international travellers, these men and women return each year to the villages and tribes to which they belong. The film makers contrast the work and leisure activities of the flight crew personnel abroad with the traditional culture, lore, and tribal values that continue to be the mainstay of the villages they come from to comment on the changes that are facing the inhabitants of Papua New Guinea and its surrounding islands at the end of the twentieth century.

results.title: Last of the windjammers
results.creator_credit: Athol Emerton and New England Film Productions
results.brief_description: A record of the departure from Newcastle of the barque Lawhill, one of the last of the square riggers to visit Australia. With a background of sea chanties, the scenes of the unfurling of the great sails of the stately vessel convey a vivid impression of the days of the windjammers.

results.title: Last hunting ground
results.brief_description: A fishing trip by the “Southern Bluefin”, one of the Safcol fishing fleet hunting for the Southern Blue Fin tuna along the South Australian coast. Shows the crew in action spotting and catching fish for two days and then returning home with a load of Blue Fin tuna. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Last hour clash (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Agency for Instructional Television and Exxon Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Heart of Teaching”.
Considers frustration’s teachers feel when they are unable to reach certain students. Shows a few ways teachers may deal with those frustration’s.

results.title: Last chance for the lucky country
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The six programs use archival material, case studies of products and people and comparisons with other nations to show how Australia has fallen behind other nations through not utilizing its intellectual and enterpreneurial talent. The programs are: “Cringe dwellers” tells how some of our world firsts were stolen by more resourceful countries. “The Backward frontiers” looks at rural innovations. “Desperately seeking solutions” compares our research and development with Japan and U.S.A. “Ordinary people, extraordinary ideas” looks at the future of innovation. “Inventing the future” a view of the new breed of entrepreneurs. “Up the J curve” the story of our industrial decay, pointing to the light at the end of the tunnel. Accompanied by one teacher’s guide and student activities.

results.title: Lasers: an introduction
results.brief_description: Principles of laser operation are illustrated, including concepts of coherent and incoherent light, continuous and discrete spectra, stimulation of atoms, and resonance. Gaseous and crystalline lasers are shown to be valuable tools of holography, communications, medicine and industry.

results.title: Laser: the light of the future
results.creator_credit: Mauri Goldberg, National Educational Television and Prism Productions
results.brief_description: Describes the contribution of Dr Arthur Schawlow, head of the Department of Physics at Stanford University to the development of the ruby laser. An electronic organ coupled to an oscilloscope helps show why getting light “in step” is so difficult. A working model of atoms demonstrates how ordinary light is produced and how laser light is generated and controlled.
